title: Output Contracts: Why Agents Must Speak JSON
intent: Understand why strict output formats (JSON schemas) are critical for building agents you can trust, debug, and automate.

core_idea.one_liner: If an agentâ€™s output is not structured and validated, it is not reliable.
why_it_matters: Humans can tolerate vague text; systems cannot.
JSON turns an agent from a narrator into a component.
Validation prevents silent failures and misinterpretation.

definition.output_contract: A predefined, machine-readable structure that the agent must follow when producing results (usually JSON with a schema).

why_free_text_fails: Ambiguity: different readers interpret it differently.
Hidden mistakes: errors are buried in prose.
No guarantees: you cannot assert correctness.
agent_rules: The agent must not add extra fields.
The agent must not change field meanings.
If required data is missing, the agent must set a flag or return an explicit error object.
No explanations outside the contract unless explicitly requested.

micro_example.bad_output: This looks like a replication issue and is probably high priority.

failure_modes: Overloaded fields (one field used for many meanings)
Mixing explanation text into structured output
guards: Reject or retry on validation failure.

teach_it_in_english.simple_explanation: JSON is a contract. It tells the agent: this is how you are allowed to speak.
teach_it_in_english.one_sentence_definition: An output contract makes AI behavior predictable and safe.

practical_checklist: Would two agents produce comparable outputs?
Can I safely feed this into another system?
